post_title: Research team develops reconfigurable photonic computing architecture for lifelong learning
title: Photonic Computing for Lifelong Learning: Overcoming "Catastrophic Forgetting"
post_content:
As AI tasks become increasingly complex and abundant, energy consumption has become a significant barrier to more widespread applications of today's heavy electronic deep neural models, especially in terminal/edge systems. The community is seeking next-generation computing modalities to overcome the physical constraints of electronics-based implementations of artificial neural networks (ANNs). Photonic computing has emerged as a promising avenue for overcoming the limitations of electronics and improving energy efficiency, processing speed, and computational throughput by orders of magnitude. Such extraordinary properties have been exploited to construct application-specific optical architectures for solving fundamental mathematical and signal processing problems with performances far beyond those of existing electronic processors.
However, existing optical neural networks (ONNs) still suffer from "catastrophic forgetting," which is the widespread problem of conventional computing systems that are prone to training new models that interfere with formerly learned knowledge, rapidly forgetting the expertise gained from previously learned tasks when trained on something new.
Such an approach fails to fully exploit the intrinsic properties in sparsity and parallelism of wave optics for photonic computing, which ultimately results in poor network capacity and scalability for multi-task learning.
In a recent paper published in Light: Science & Applications, a team of scientists, led by Professor Lu Fang from Sigma Laboratory, Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, and co-workers have developed L2ONN, a reconfigurable photonic computing architecture for lifelong learning.
The unique characteristics of light, spatial sparsity, and multi-spectrum parallelism have been developed in photonic computing architecture for the first time, endowing ONNs with lifelong learning capability. Unlike existing ONNs that try to imitate ANN structures, the photonic lifelong learning of L2ONN is initially designed following the physical nature of light–matter interaction, to fully explore the functional and performance potentials of wave optics in photonic computing.
Benefiting from the proposed lifelong-learning optical computing architecture, experimental evaluations on free-space and on-chip architectures demonstrate that L2ONN shows its extraordinary learning capability on challenging tens-of-tasks, such as vision classification, voice recognition, and medical diagnosis, supporting various new environments.
L2ONN achieves up to 14 times larger capacity than existing optical neural networks, with an order of magnitude higher energy efficiency than the representative electronic artificial neural networks.
"Humans possess the unique ability to incrementally absorb, learn, and memorize knowledge. In particular, neurons and synapses perform work only when there are tasks to deal with, in which two important mechanisms participate: sparse neuron connectivity and parallelly task-driven neurocognition, together contribute to a lifelong memory consolidation and retrieval.
"Accordingly, in ONNs, these characteristic features can be naturally promoted from biological neurons to photonic neurons based on the intrinsic sparsity and parallelism properties of optical operators.
"An optical architecture imitating the structure and function of human brains demonstrates its potential to alleviate the aforementioned issues, which shows more advantages than electronic approaches in constructing a viable lifelong learning computing system.
"We have demonstrated the photonic lifelong learning provides a turnkey solution for large-scale real-life AI applications with unprecedented scalability and versatility. We anticipate that the proposed neuromorphic architecture will accelerate the development of more powerful photonic computing as critical support for modern advanced machine intelligence and towards beginning a new era of AI," stated the scientists.
In conclusion, photonic computing has emerged as a promising avenue for overcoming the limitations of electronics and improving energy efficiency, processing speed, and computational throughput by orders of magnitude. L2ONN, a reconfigurable photonic computing architecture for lifelong learning, has demonstrated its extraordinary learning capability on challenging tens-of-tasks, supporting various new environments. The proposed architecture has the potential to alleviate the issues of "catastrophic forgetting" and provide a turnkey solution for large-scale real-life AI applications with unprecedented scalability and versatility. The development of more powerful photonic computing as critical support for modern advanced machine intelligence will accelerate and usher in a new era of AI.

post_title: The White House tells NASA to create a new time zone for the Moon
title: "White House Directs NASA to Create Lunar Time Zone"
post_content:
On Tuesday, the White House released a policy memo that directed NASA to create a new time standard for the Moon by 2026. This new time reference, Coordinated Lunar Time (LTC), will help guide future lunar missions. The memo came as a 21st-century space race emerged between the US, China, Japan, India, and Russia.

NASA has been instructed to work with several government departments, including Commerce, Defense, State, and Transportation, to plan a strategy for implementing LTC by December 31, 2026. International cooperation will also be crucial, particularly with signatories of the Artemis Accords, a set of common principles that govern space exploration and operating principles. Although China and Russia are not part of the group, they have expressed interest in establishing their own time standards.

The memo highlights the importance of establishing a consistent definition of time among operators in space. This is critical for successful space situational awareness capabilities, navigation, and communications, all of which are foundational for interoperability across the US government and with international partners.

According to Einstein's theories of relativity, time changes relative to speed and gravity. Given the Moon's weaker gravity and movement differences between it and Earth, time moves slightly faster there. As the US and other countries plan Moon missions to research, explore, and eventually build bases for permanent residence, using a single standard will help them synchronize technology and missions requiring precise timing.

NASA's Artemis program aims to send crewed missions back to the Moon for the first time since the Apollo missions of the 1960s and 70s. The space agency has set a launch date of September 2025 for Artemis 2, which will fly around the Moon with four people onboard, and a launch date of 2026 for Artemis 3, which plans to put humans back on the Moon's surface.

In addition to the US, China aims to put astronauts on the Moon before 2030 as the world's two foremost global superpowers take their race to space. Although no other countries have announced crewed missions to the lunar surface, India, Russia, the United Arab Emirates, Japan, South Korea, and private companies have all demonstrated lunar ambitions in recent years.

Furthermore, establishing a lunar time standard will enable further scientific exploration, technological establishment, and resource mining. The Moon could also serve as a critical stop on the way to Mars. It could test technologies and provide fuel and supply needs for eventual human missions to the Red Planet.

In conclusion, the White House's policy memo directing NASA to create a new time standard for the Moon is a significant step towards establishing a consistent definition of time among operators in space. The new Coordinated Lunar Time (LTC) will help guide future lunar missions, maintain resilience, and enable interoperability across the US government and with international partners. The Moon could also serve as a critical stop on the way to Mars, testing technologies and providing fuel and supply needs for eventual human missions.

title: Kiwibot Acquires Taiwanese Chipmaker Amidst US-China Tensions; Cites Cybersecurity as Key Motivator
post_content:
In recent news, Kiwibot, a Bay Area-based delivery robotics company with operations in Colombia, has announced the acquisition of Auto Mobility Solutions, a Taipei-based firm that produces chips specifically for the robotics and autonomous driving industries. The terms of the transaction have not been disclosed, but Kiwi founder and CEO Felipe Chávez Cortés has stated that rising tensions between the U.S. and China are a major motivator for the purchase.

Kiwibot calls the deal a "significant milestone" for both companies, citing their shared commitment to innovation and protecting privacy in the robotics industry, particularly when it comes to intelligent robots sourced from China and deployed in Western markets. This acquisition is likely to set a precedent for many in the industry, given the recent focus on ByteDance's TikTok social media platform and the U.S. government's efforts to pressure Chinese tech giants such as Huawei and DJI.

Taiwan's geopolitical situation, coupled with its significant share of the semiconductor market, has made it a focal point in the conflict between the U.S. and China. Some government officials have even suggested that the U.S. should bomb Taiwanese chip giant TSMC if China invades the island nation, as controlling the company's facilities would give a country a near monopoly on certain chip verticals. While smaller operations like Auto Mobility Solutions may not be an immediate focus, their presence in Asia, particularly in Taiwan and China, highlights the growing importance of the region in the global tech industry.

In a statement tied to the news, Chávez Cortés cited cybersecurity concerns as a key motivator for the acquisition. "The acquisition of Auto is a game-changer for us, bringing a wealth of technological innovation and a strong patent portfolio that will significantly enhance our cybersecurity measures for AI-powered robotics," he said. "This move not only strengthens our position in the market but also connects the manufacturing expertise from Asia with the AI development in the West securely."

Kiwibot says the deal will also help the UC Berkeley spinout establish a presence in Asia, given Auto's footprint in Taiwan and China. To date, Kiwi has found its biggest successes on college campuses, but this acquisition marks a strategic move to expand its reach beyond North America.

In conclusion, Kiwibot's acquisition of Auto Mobility Solutions is a significant milestone for both companies, reflecting their shared commitment to innovation and protecting privacy in the robotics industry. As tensions between the U.S. and China continue to escalate, the importance of establishing a strong presence in Asia becomes increasingly evident for companies operating in the global tech industry. With cybersecurity concerns at the forefront of their minds, Kiwi and Auto Mobility Solutions are taking proactive steps to safeguard their operations and ensure the success of their AI-powered robotics.

post_title: Study shows magnetic fields boosts electrocatalysis for sustainable fuel production
title: Magnetic Fields Revolutionize Clean Energy Production with 50% Boost
post_content:
Title: Harnessing Magnetic Forces to Revolutionize Clean Energy Production

In the quest for sustainable energy sources, the scientific community is constantly exploring innovative methods to enhance fuel production processes. One such method is electrocatalysis, which plays a crucial role in converting chemical energy into electrical energy and vice versa. Electrocatalysis involves the use of catalysts to speed up electrochemical reactions without being consumed in the process. This technique is essential in devices like fuel cells and electrolyzers, where it enables the efficient transformation of fuels into electricity or water into hydrogen and oxygen, respectively.

However, traditional electrocatalysis methods often face a significant challenge: maximizing the transport of reactants to the catalyst's surface. This critical step is essential for achieving optimal reaction efficiency, which remains elusive in current clean energy solutions. To tackle this issue, a team of researchers led by Magalí Lingenfelder at EPFL has developed a novel approach that combines magnetic fields and electrocatalysis to enhance the efficiency of clean fuel production. Their research was published in Nature Communications.

The study demonstrates that surrounding catalysts with magnetic fields generates Lorentz forces, which, in turn, induce whirling motions that enhance the movement of reactants and products at the catalyst surface. This results in a more consistent and rapid reaction, overcoming limitations posed by reactant scarcity, a common hurdle in reactions like the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), critical for fuel cells.

To observe the movement of ions in real-time under a magnetic field, the researchers developed an advanced magneto-electrochemical setup. This setup enabled them to decouple the different effects and observe how magnetic forces can stir and enhance the movement of reactants around the catalyst, akin to creating miniature whirlpools. This process significantly improves the efficiency of reactions crucial for green hydrogen production, offering a promising avenue for advancing sustainable energy technologies.

The research team, led by Magalí Lingenfelder at EPFL, showcased a more than 50% boost in activity for the oxygen reduction reaction induced by magnetic fields on non-magnetic interfaces. This substantial increase in efficiency allows for the resolution of many fundamental controversies in the field, demonstrating the mechanisms and conditions needed for magnetic fields to enhance different electrocatalytic reactions involving gas products or reactants

Title: 3D Magnetic Recording Breakthrough: Boosting HDD Storage Capacity

In a groundbreaking feat, scientists showcase multi-level recording with 3D magnetic medium, paving the way for enhanced hard disk drives. DataStorage Innovation
post_content:
Title: A Breakthrough in Data Storage: Multi-level Recording with 3D Magnetic Recording Medium

In a significant breakthrough for the field of data storage, researchers from NIMS, Seagate Technology, and Tohoku University have demonstrated the potential of multi-level recording using a three-dimensional magnetic recording medium. This innovation could pave the way for increased storage capacity and more cost-effective hard disk drives (HDDs) in the future.

Currently, data centers store vast amounts of data on HDDs that utilize perpendicular magnetic recording (PMR) to store information at areal densities of approximately 1.5 Tbit/in2. However, to transition to higher areal densities, a high anisotropy magnetic recording medium consisting of FePt grains combined with heat-assisted laser writing is required. This method, known as heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), can sustain areal recording densities of up to 10 Tbit/in2. Moreover, densities larger than 10 Tbit/in2 are feasible based on a new principle demonstrated by storing multiple recording levels of 3 or 4 compared to the binary level used in HDD technology.

The research team has successfully arranged the FePt recording layers three-dimensionally by fabricating lattice-matched, FePt/Ru/FePt multilayer films, with Ru as a spacer layer. Measurements of the magnetization reveal that the two FePt layers have different Curie temperatures. This discovery allows for three-dimensional recording by adjusting the laser power when writing.

The researchers also demonstrated the principle of 3D recording through recording simulations. They utilized a media model that mimics the microstructure and magnetic properties of the fabricated media. The three-dimensional magnetic recording method can increase recording capacity by stacking recording layers in three dimensions. This means that more digital information can be stored with fewer HDDs, leading to energy savings for data centers.

In the future, the researchers aim to develop processes to reduce the size of FePt grains, improve the orientation and magnetic anisotropy, and stack more FePt layers. The goal is to realize a media structure suitable for practical use as a high-density HDD. This innovative approach to data storage using a three-dimensional magnetic recording medium could revolutionize the industry and lead to significant advancements

Aerospike's unique selling proposition lies in its hybrid memory architecture, which combines RAM and fast flash storage. Aerospike plans to use the new funding to develop its AI capabilities further, focusing on combining graph and vector functionalities. This integration could lead to more powerful applications, as Aerospike's graph capabilities could help users discover related documents or data points after a vector search has narrowed down the choices.

post_title: Coalesce raises more cash to transform data for Snowflake customers
title: Coalesce raises $50 million to enhance data transformation for Snowflake customers: Data Transformation and Optimization: Challenges and Solutions
post_content:
Data Transformation and Optimization: Challenges and Solutions

In today's fast-paced business world, data transformation and optimization have become essential tasks for many organizations. However, these challenges seem to increase with the growth of AI and cloud technologies. According to a recent Gartner poll, only 44% of data and analytics leaders believe their teams are effective in providing value to their organization, mainly due to insufficient resources, funding, and skilled staffers.

Armon Petrossian and Satish Jayanthi, former sales manager and senior solutions architect at WhereScape, respectively, faced these challenges while working on data warehousing problems for their clients. After six years at WhereScape, they decided to start Coalesce, a San Francisco-based company that provides a suite of data transformation services, apps, and tools.

Coalesce's mission is to radically improve the analytics landscape by making enterprise-scale data transformations as efficient and flexible as possible, allowing organizations to quickly move to implementing and taking advantage of AI and large language models. The company has recently closed a $50 million Series B funding round co-led by Industry Ventures and Emergency Capital, bringing their total raised to $81 million.

The Data Transformation Layer: A Bottleneck in Analytics

Data transformation and optimization are critical for organizations to gain valuable insights from their data. However, data science and engineering teams spend the majority of their time on data prep, which includes data cleansing and transformations, manually coding and building out data pipelines, and getting the data from source to dashboard or other business uses. These manual processes are time-consuming, labor-intensive, and don't scale.

To address this challenge, Coalesce has built a platform that standardizes data while automating the more repetitive, mundane data transformation processes. Using Coalesce, data science teams can employ metadata to manage transformations with an understanding of how the different pieces of data are linked and connected. This reduces the time and effort required in data transformation and optimization, ultimately resulting in faster time-to-value for the organization's data.

Coalesce's platform is built to work exclusively with Snowflake's Data Cloud product, and Snowflake's corporate VC arm, Snowflake Ventures, is an investor. However, Petrossian believes that Coalesce's focus on enterprise Fortune 500 companies makes it more resilient to economic shifts and market headwinds.

Competition in the Data Transformation Tool Market

Coalesce isn't the only data transformation tool vendor in the market. Other vendors, such as Dbt and legacy extract, transform, and load (ETL) tools like Informatica and Talend, could be considered rivals. However, Petrossian believes that Coalesce's focus on enterprise Fortune 500 companies and its ability to offer a scalable and efficient platform set it apart from the competition.

Coalesce's Roadmap

Coalesce plans to focus on improving the Coalesce platform's performance, introducing AI features, and reaching out to existing Snowflake customers. The company aims to expand its 80-person team to around 100 by the end of the year. Petrossian hinted that generative AI and machine learning applications could be force multipliers for Coalesce's business.

Conclusion

In conclusion, data transformation and optimization are essential tasks for organizations to gain valuable insights from their data. However, these challenges increase with the growth of AI and cloud technologies. Coalesce's platform, which standardizes data while automating the more repetitive, mundane data transformation processes, offers a solution to this challenge. The company's focus on enterprise Fortune 500 companies and its ability to offer a scalable and efficient platform set it apart from the competition. With a clear roadmap for expansion and innovation, Coalesce is well-positioned to continue its growth in the data transformation tool market.

post_title: DataStax acquires the startup behind low-code AI builder Langflow
title: DataStax acquires Logspace for generative AI stack development with Langflow.
post_content:
DataStax, a company that made its name by commercializing the open-source Apache Cassandra NoSQL database, has recently shifted its focus to building a "one-stop GenAI stack." To achieve this, the company has been working to improve its hosted Astra DB service, which now includes vector search capabilities. The latest step in this direction is the acquisition of Logspace, the company behind Langflow, a low-code tool for building Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) applications.

Founded in 2022, Logspace aimed to help businesses adopt machine learning. Initially, the company was more of a consultancy than a product company. The co-founder and CEO, Rodrigo Nader, previously worked on machine learning problems at enterprise AI company Bitvore, together with co-founder and CTO Gabriel Luiz Freitas Almeida. They self-funded the company and launched Langflow, an early open-source low-code/no-code tool for creating GenAI apps, which quickly gained some traction.

DataStax announced that it had acquired Logspace, although the price of the acquisition was not disclosed. The company argues that this acquisition effectively completes its effort to build a one-stop generative AI stack. With Langflow, DataStax can now offer its users a single tool that combines built-in connections to DataStax's own Astra DB and tools like the LangChain toolkit and LlamaIndex for connecting different data sources, with an easy-to-use visual editor for building GenAI chatbots for internal and external use.

Langflow will continue to operate as a separate entity, so existing users shouldn't notice any immediate changes. The DataStax team is excited about the acquisition and believes that it will enable developers to put their wild new generative AI ideas on a fast path to production. Nader, the co-founder and CEO of Logspace, is equally enthusiastic about joining the DataStax team and supercharging the Langflow platform's ability to grow and bring it to more researchers, developers, enterprises, and entrepreneurs working on generative AI applications.

In conclusion, DataStax's acquisition of Logspace represents a significant step towards building a comprehensive generative AI stack. With Langflow, DataStax can offer its users a single tool that simplifies the process of building RAG-based applications backed by Retrieval-Augmented Generation. The acquisition will provide current Langflow developers and current DataStax developers with additional resources and integrations to elevate their applications to match the scale of their ambitions.

The update also includes several smaller improvements, such as the ability to change preferred languages per Android app through “Settings > Apps > Manage your apps > App language.” This feature allows users to tailor their browsing experience to their needs and preferences. Additionally, the text-to-speech feature has been improved, with a voice that should sound more natural. This feature works even when you’re offline, making it a valuable tool for users who need to access information on the go.

Overall, the ChromeOS M123 update is a significant improvement for users, bringing new features that make it easier to customize their browsing experience and improve their productivity. With these updates, ChromeOS continues to cement its position as a leading operating system for both desktop and mobile devices.

title:
Title: Big Tech's ICT Workforce Consortium Tackles AI Job Impact Concerns

Aims to skill 95M worldwide in AI jobs by 2030, addressing 56 ICT roles.
post_content:
Title: The AI-Enabled ICT Workforce Consortium: A New Approach to AI and Jobs

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is increasingly becoming a part of our daily lives and workplaces. While it promises to revolutionize industries and bring about significant advancements, there are concerns about its impact on jobs. According to recent surveys, many workers fear that AI could lead to job losses due to automation. In response to these concerns, a group of Big Tech vendors and consultancies, known as the AI-Enabled ICT Workforce Consortium (ITC), aims to address the potential impact of AI on jobs within the information and communication technology (ICT) industry.

The ITC is led by Cisco and includes Google, Microsoft, IBM, Intel, SAP, and Accenture. The consortium's mission is to study AI's effects on ICT jobs, provide training recommendations, and connect businesses with skilled and job-ready workers. The ITC's unique approach involves researching and evaluating the impact of AI on 56 ICT job roles, chosen for their strategic significance and the promising entry points they offer for low-level workers.

In the first phase of its work, the ITC will assess AI's impact on these 56 roles and provide training recommendations for those affected. The job roles were selected based on their strategic significance in the broader ICT ecosystem and AI's impact on the tasks required to perform the roles. The consortium will publish its findings in a report this summer.

However, delivering vague promises and reports might not be enough to allay workers' fears. Tech companies must take concrete actions to address the impact of AI on jobs. IBM and Intel, for instance, have pledged to skill millions of people in AI by 2030. The ITC aims to positively impact over 95 million individuals worldwide over the next 10 years through skills development and training programs.

Despite these ambitious goals, there is uncertainty about the number of AI roles that will be available in the future. According to a recent analysis by Lightcast, a labor market analytics firm, the demand for AI roles in the U.S. decreased from 2% in 2022 to 1.6% in 2023. The ITC, however, remains committed to developing worker pathways in job sectors that will increasingly integrate AI technology

post_content:
Flipkart Co-Founder Sachin Bansal Seeks $2 Billion Valuation for Fintech Startup Navi

Sachin Bansal, the co-founder of e-commerce giant Flipkart, is reportedly in discussions with investors to secure funding for his fintech startup, Navi, at a valuation of around $2 billion. According to sources who spoke to TechCrunch, Bansal aims to raise between $200 million and $400 million in this funding round, which would be Navi's first significant outside fundraising since its inception in 2018.

Navi, which offers personal loans, home loans, and health insurance, initially aimed to raise $440 million through an initial public offering (IPO). However, due to the sluggish IPO market, the startup abandoned these plans in 2022. Bansal has primarily self-funded Navi up to this point.

Although discussions are ongoing, no deal has been finalized. The terms and Bansal's interest in outside funding may change during the negotiations. A Navi spokesperson declined to comment on the matter.

This development in the venture market indicates a significant shift in India and signals a potential revival of growth-stage funding rounds for fintech businesses worldwide. The funding discussions follow a challenging 2023 in India's startup ecosystem, which experienced a 73% decline in overall funding.

Several other Indian startups, including Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund ADIA-backed audio-storytelling platform Pocket FM, Indian eyewear brand Lenskart, Temasek-backed consumer nutrition platform HealthKart, and bike-taxi aggregator Rapido, are also in talks to raise new growth-stage rounds.

Bansal's approach to Navi is a departure from his time at Flipkart, where he raised billions of dollars from a prestigious list of strategic and financial investors. After leaving Flipkart in 2018 with a $1 billion windfall, Bansal opted for a self-funded approach for Navi. Before the IPO filing, he engaged in discussions with potential investors, including SoftBank, but these talks stalled when Navi's application for a banking license was rejected

Title: A Major Leap Towards Practical Quantum Computing: Microsoft and Quantinuum's Error-Free System

Introduction

Quantum computing holds the promise of revolutionizing the world with its potential to solve complex calculations exponentially faster than classical computers. Although we've seen incremental advancements in quantum hardware from industry leaders like IBM and Google, these machines have yet to be used for practical purposes. That is, until now. Microsoft and Quantinuum recently announced the development of the most error-free quantum computing system to date. Let's dive into the details of this groundbreaking achievement and what it means for the future of quantum computing.

post_title: Business planning startup Pigment raises $145M in rare French tech mega-round
title: Paris-Based Startup Pigment Raises $145 Million in Series D Funding Round
post_content:
Title: Paris-Based Startup Pigment Raises $145 Million in Series D Funding Round

Paris-based startup Pigment has raised a massive $145 million in a Series D funding round, just five years after its inception. The enterprise software company offers a business planning platform for large companies to visualize their past financial performance and forecast upcoming quarters.

This funding round comes as a pleasant surprise, given the recent downturn in funding rounds in the French tech ecosystem, according to a recent study by EY. In 2023, funding rounds in the French tech ecosystem were down 38% compared to 2022. However, if we exclude buzzy AI startups like Mistral AI and capital-intensive infrastructure plays that are not really tech startups, like EV charging networks (Driveco) and EV battery factories (Verkor), funding rounds are drastically down.

Pigment appears as an exception with its Series D, led by existing investor Iconiq Growth, who is doubling down on this new funding round. Sandberg Bernthal Venture Partners, IVP, Meritech, Greenoaks, and Felix Capital are also participating in the round, with many of them being existing investors as well.

The reason behind Pigment's successful raise is its remarkable growth. In the past year, the startup tripled its revenue and doubled its customer base, with well-known clients like Unilever, Datadog, Kayak, and Merck. Half of Pigment's clients are based in the U.S.

Pigment's co-founder and co-CEO, Eléonore Crespo, shared with me that their current investors told them, "if you're going to raise money in 18 months to scale with others, we might as well offer you great terms right now for an internal round." Everything happened quickly, with the funding round being completed in one week.

Before founding Pigment, Crespo worked for VC firm Index Ventures and Google. She co-founded Pigment with Romain Niccoli, who was the co-founder and CTO of adtech startup Criteo - an early success of the French tech ecosystem.

Pigment is a flexible business planning tool that is used by chief financial officers and finance teams to create reports and budgets. It's a modern SaaS platform, meaning that you can integrate it with all your company's data (ERP, HRIS, data lakes, etc.) and use it as a collaboration tool.

In addition to finance teams, sales teams can use Pigment to create quotas and see how everyone is performing against quarterly quotas. HR teams can see how they should scale the workforce up and down based on strategic changes and financial objectives.

As more teams start using Pigment, it becomes an important tool for cross-team collaboration. And it's supposed to work better than legacy tools from Oracle and SAP.

Like many software companies, Pigment has also added AI features. As Pigment acts as the central repository for all the important metrics of a company, customers can ask questions to Pigment AI in natural language to get a quick answer. Examples include "Can you give me a breakdown of revenue per country?" or "Why was our actual revenue lower than our forecast last quarter for this product?"

However, what sets Pigment apart is its optimization of its core product to work well even with large datasets and complicated calculations. The best enterprise software products are must-have products, which means that companies usually don't need to spend a lot of resources on improving the product - clients need this tool to operate. Pigment is still the challenger in this industry, so it believes it needs to provide a better product to compete with other business planning products.

In conclusion, Pigment's successful Series D funding round is a testament to its exceptional growth and unique value proposition. As the company continues to innovate and provide a better product, it's poised to become a leader in the enterprise software space.

post_title: Exploring the resilience of the Texas power grid against extreme weather conditions
title: "New Study Reveals How Texas Power Grid Resilience Can Be Improved Against Extreme Weather"
post_content:
The Gulf Coast of the United States is no stranger to extreme weather events, including hurricanes and tropical cyclones. These events can cause widespread power outages that disrupt activities in the area. Climate change and global warming are expected to increase the risk of these events occurring, which could have significant consequences.

Recently, researchers at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research (PIK) and Fraunhofer SCAI in Germany conducted a study to investigate the impact of extreme weather events on the Texas power grid. Their paper, published in Nature Energy, could guide efforts by local governments and engineers in the area aimed at increasing the resilience of the electricity grid in the state of Texas.

The study's primary objective was to understand the interplay between evolving storm conditions and the partially destroyed state of the grid. This required the researchers to study the temporal-spatial structure of damages and outages, a topic with little preexisting research.

The researchers' approach differed from previous efforts in this field in that they did not only fail lines that were most likely to trigger outages in the unperturbed fully functional systems but also examined their impact in instances where a power grid had already suffered extensive damages. This allowed them to better determine the "backbone" of the grid, which supports its resilience.

According to Anvari, the paper is an interdisciplinary collaboration between impact modeling and infrastructure research carried out at PIK. "Recent studies and statistics have shown a significant increase in power outages caused by extreme weather events. Our study focuses on extreme wind events, which have a significant impact on transmission lines and towers. Damage caused by extremely windy weather events to transmission lines often leads to further system and infrastructure failures, resulting in widespread blackouts and power outages."

The researchers' approach involves using a key intuition rooted in complex systems research. This intuition is that if a complex but robust system fails due to external stresses, it typically does so following fairly well-defined patterns or failure modes. If these failure modes can be identified, it may be possible to prevent catastrophic failures.

In this study, the researchers identified critical lines that are most likely to trigger large-scale blackouts during extreme wind events. They recommend enhancing the resilience of these lines by replacing overhead lines with underground cables to ensure 100% safety against wind damage.

The study's findings could help guide efforts by local governments and engineers in the area aimed at increasing the resilience of the electricity grid in the state of Texas. By understanding the interplay between evolving storm conditions and the partially destroyed state of the grid, the researchers were able to identify the critical lines that support the grid's resilience and develop strategies to enhance their resilience against extreme wind events.

post_title: Apple reportedly exploring AI-powered home robots, including these two products
title: Apple explores personal home robots; mobile assistant, tabletop with moving display. Early development under AI chief Giannandrea.
post_content:
In recent years, Apple has undergone several significant shifts in its product roadmap. The company has decided to end its electric car project and focus on developing its presence in the AI space. Apple's next potential pivot may be into home robotics.

On Wednesday, Apple analyst Mark Gurman reported that the company is exploring the development of personal robots. The possible products include a mobile robot assistant that follows users around their homes and an advanced tabletop device with a moving display powered by robotics.

This development is reportedly happening under John Giannandrea, Apple's senior vice president of machine learning and AI strategy, who previously led machine intelligence, research, and search teams at Google. Matt Costello and Brian Lynch, two Apple executives in the hardware group, have overseen the hardware development of the robots, according to the report.

However, since the developments are in their early stages, and the company has not yet committed to the projects, there is no guarantee that the products will be released.

This isn't the first time Apple has considered creating a tabletop device with a display. In February, 9to5Mac reported that the company was working on an unreleased device that resembled a HomePod with a screen.

Even though this would be Apple's first time creating a home robot, it wouldn't be the first home robot to hit the market. Amazon has its robot assistant Astro, which it launched in 2021, and Samsung has its home assistant Ballie, a bowling ball-sized robot that can double as a projector, smart home hub, and more, and is expected to hit the market in 2024.

Today's report comes after Apple researchers published a research paper introducing the company's Reference Resolution As Language Modeling (ReALM), a model that could potentially improve Siri's conversational abilities.

Whether Apple's home robots hit the market or not, one thing is for sure -- the company is gearing up to become a major player in the AI and robotics space. We may get a glimpse of this latest AI push at WWDC in June.
